I got this definition of dictionary.com.  Of all the defs they had there this
seemed the most applicable:

"Change in the genetic composition of a population during successive
generations, as a result of natural selection acting on the genetic variation
among individuals, and resulting in the development of new species."

Most of the other definiions included some form of "change for the better" or
"increasing complexity", so it sounds like it implies something more than
random change.

> Granted,
> there are cases where there is only random selection,
> and hence genetic drift is the only source of gene
> frequency change

It's a trivial point, but is random selection still selection?  Is there any
difference between not having a fitness function, and having a random fitness function?
